prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Shirley.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Mary, Shirley, Karen, Rebecca, Nicholas, Margaret, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Shirley's) goal: Deceive others, avoid detection, and eliminate villagers.

{secret}

prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Mary.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Mary, Shirley, Karen, Rebecca, Nicholas, Margaret, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Mary's) goal: Act openly and collaboratively to identify werewolves.

{secret}

Here is the context of the interaction:


Conversation Starts:

Turn #0: [Game] State: Night_werewolf. The game begins!

Turn #1: [Game] Entering state: Night_seer

Turn #2: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #3: [Game] Nicholas was killed by werewolves!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #4: Mary: said: "Nicholas has been killed by the werewolves. We need to figure out who among us is a werewolf. I'm not sure about anyone yet, but I think we should focus on discussing the possible suspects based on who might have been killed and who might have had a reason to do so. Let's keep an open mind and look for inconsistencies in the players' behavior or statements."

Turn #5: Shirley: said: ""I agree with Mary that we need to scrutinize everyone's statements closely. Last night, the wolves successfully took out Nicholas, which is a big loss for us. I think we should consider who had interactions with him. Did anyone notice strange behavior or suspicious comments from him or others leading up to this? That might give us a clue about the werewolves among us.""

Turn #6: Karen: said: "I think we should keep an open mind, but I noticed that Margaret was inspected by Karen last night and she is a villager. That might help us rule her out as a werewolf. I don't have any direct evidence against anyone else, but I'll be watching for any suspicious behavior or inconsistencies in the others' statements."

Turn #7: Rebecca: said: ""I find it interesting that Karen is trying to clear Margaret so quickly. It makes me wonder why she feels the need to defend her. We should also look more closely at Karen's behavior since she was the last to interact with Nicholas before his death. Can anyone else remember their interactions with him?""

Turn #8: Margaret: said: "I appreciate the discussion so far. Karen's point about me being inspected and being a villager is valid, and I'm glad we're focusing on transparency. I want to emphasize that I am not a werewolf and have no hidden agenda. As someone who values open communication, I believe we should all remain honest and trust the process. I also agree with Rebecca that we should look at interactions with Nicholas more closely. If anyone noticed anything unusual in his behavior or if there were any patterns of suspicion, I encourage sharing that. Let's keep the discussion fair, constructive, and focused on uncovering the truth together."
